awd_titl_txt: Activated and nonlinear kinetics in biomolecules and interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Dimitry Matyushov of Arizona State University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program in the Division of Chemistry for theoretical and computational studies of proteins.   Proteins provide the main building material of cells and multicellular organisms. In addition, protein enzymes are working horses of the cell catalyzing all chemical reactions required for life. All energy of life is produced and stored by moving electrons in protons across the cellular membrane, a function performed by membrane-bound proteins. At the same time, 80% of the cell's volume is water, which mostly exists in its interfacial form surrounding proteins and lipids of membranes. How proteins and interfacial water, the "matrix of life", couple in their function is still largely a mystery requiring both theoretical and experimental studies. The set of questions, addressed by this project, touches on the deepest problems of energy efficiency of life, its physiological energy flow, and the fundamental principles of work produced by non-equilibrium molecular systems.   Professor Matyushov and his research group are actively engaged in an outreach, research and education program involving local high school students. 


This theoretical project, which is deeply connected to experimental studies, suggests that proteins are fundamentally non-equilibrium systems in which the time-scales of protein function are often shorter than the time-scales of equilibration achieved through conformational dynamics. This non-equilibrium nature of proteins requires two temperatures: the configurational temperature of the non-equilibrium protein and the standard thermodynamic temperature of the surrounding bath.  Computational studies performed in the previous funding cycle have shown that proteins are up to three times "hotter"than water. A direct consequence of this perspective is a strong depression of the reaction activation barrier. The catalytic action of the enzyme is very much a function of its non-equilibrium state, which ages to the ?dead state? of the Gibbs distribution due to conformational dynamics exploring the configuration space. The aging process has to be terminated and the enzyme reset before this equilibrium state is reached.  The project connects enzymatic efficiency of redox active proteins with the protein-water interfacial structure and glassy aging dynamics of collective variables linked to the activated barrier crossing.   


The project addresses the following practical questions: (a) Configurational temperature of redox proteins and the dynamics of equilibration with the thermal bath. (b) Theories and simulations of interfacial susceptibility of water and its distinction from water in the bulk. This problem connects to a number of experimental techniques such as depolarized light scattering, THz absorption, dielectric spectroscopy, and protein dielectrophoresis. (c) A theory of non-linear dielectric response of solutions applied to testing of interfaces. Collaborative initiatives as a part of the project aim at linking theory to experiment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main focus of this project was to study activated kinetics of charge transfer in proteins and polarization of water interfaces. The intellectual motivation of our studies came from the idea that proteins are sluggish, glassy media and were evolutionary selected to be such to gain catalytic function. This general view was separated into several projects aiming to demonstrate that  a number of alternative physical mechanisms, specific to proteins, lead to lower reaction barriers for redox reactions catalyzed by natural enzymes. The theoretical project combined high-performance computer simulations with the development of formal theories for activated kinetics bridging between computations and laboratory experiments. The connection between theory and kinetic measurements is allowed by protein electrochemistry and much of our effort was directed to constructing models for heterogeneous protein electron transfer.  We found that protein dynamics become a significant parameter, in addition to the thermodynamic reaction free energy, that can be used by natural selection and by artificial design to tune catalytic performance of enzymes.   Much of the physics of enzymatic function is related to specifics of the protein-water interface. We explored the dynamics and statistics of the protein-water interface and developed theories of polarization and effective dielectric constant of aqueous interfaces. The effective dielectric constant of water at electrified interfaces turned out to be significantly reduced compared to the bulk. The same phenomenology was found for the protein-water interface. At the same time, the dynamics of the electric field produced by water shells inside proteins was found to be slowed down by four orders of magnitude compared to small molecules dissolved in water. This result has an observable consequence in substantial narrowing of spectroscopic lines of vibrational probes placed inside proteins, as was established from our analysis of computer simulations and available experimental data. Unique properties of proteins in solution can be efficiently used for their detection by spectroscopic techniques and for separation of proteins in solution. The separation problem carries significant biomedical applications. We predicted that proteins can be separated based on their electrostatic properties by dielectrophoresis, that is by their response to an inhomogeneous electric field. This approach to protein separation was viewed as inefficient in the past because of incorrect theoretical estimates of protein dielectrophoretic susceptibility. The experimental results were critically reexamined by practitioners in the field after our proposal was published, with presently a positive outlook for the development of protein separation techniques based on protein dielectrophoresis. Another potential avenue of increased sensitivity to specific proteins is the application of nonlinear dielectric techniques. Research in this direction was initiated in this funding cycle. Specifics of the protein-water interface are also seen in the mobility of proteins in the applied electric field and in protein diffusivity. Simulations of friction to translational diffusion due to protein-water electrostatics were performed with the goal of developing theories of protein diffusion under changing external conditions. We found that traditional theories of electrostatic (dielectric) friction grossly overestimate its importance and dielectric friction is in fact significantly reduced because of correlations between electrostatic and non-electrostatic forces between the protein and its water shell.  

The PI has contributed to dissemination of the project results. Journal articles, book chapters, and review articles were written. A graduate-level text ``Manual for Theoretical Chemistry'' was published by World Scientific in 2021. We continued our outreach activities involving science teaches from local high schools.
